title: Rare 2p sells for staggering £800 - and here's how to spot a valuable coin in your change
text:
Rare 2p sells for staggering £800 - and here's how to spot a valuable coin in your change Rare 2p sells for staggering £800 - and here's how to spot a valuable coin in your change A RARE silver two pence coin has raised more than £800 for a hospital after it was spotted in a collection box for unwanted currency. PUBLISHED: 14:02, Mon, Jul 20, 2015 | UPDATED: 17:03, Mon, Jul 20, 2015 Royal Berkshire Hospital The silver two-pence seen next to its regular counterpart 
The collector's piece inscribed with the words ‘new pence’ was recognised by volunteer Becky Jennings, who was sorting through donations at the Royal Berkshire Hospital in Reading. The coin is one of a number produced in 1971 after an error was though to have been made during the minting process. The proceeds from the collection go to the The Royal Berks Charity, which is used to fund vital equipment for the hospital.After being found, the unusual two-pence coin was put on auction website eBay and sold for £802.03. Mark Goff, Royal Berks charity director, said: "We’re absolutely thrilled that the coin fetched £802. Quite a mark up on 2p! "The money will be used towards vital equipment in our Urology Department. "We want to thank both the collector who bought it, and our eagle-eyed volunteer who spotted it among other coins that were donated to us as part of our ‘cash for coins’ collection, which has raised £26,500 so far for the charity." Royal Berkshire hospital Volunteer Becky Jennings found the coin Royal Berkshire Hospital The rare 2p was listed on eBay 
But the silver two-pence in not the only coin that is worth a significant amount more than its face value. Pay closer attention to the change in your pocket and you could find that you're - literally - sitting on a fortune… Kew Gardens 50p The Royal Mint The Kew Gardens 50p 
If you have a 50p coin with a design of the Kew Gardens on its face, hang on to it because it's the rarest coin in circulation. The silver piece was released in 2009 to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Royal Botanic Gardens.But only 210,000 of the coins were minted - a low number compared to 22.7million of the Royal Arms shield 50p design in 2008, and 7.5million of the Girl-guiding 50p in 2010.Only one in every 300 people in Britain are thought to have the Kew Gardens 50p in their change.As a result, the coin fetches prices among collectors of up to £120. Rare London 2012 Olympic swimming 50p coin Royal Mint The Olympic 50p where the swimmers face can be seen 
A certain number of commemorative 50p pieces celebrating Olympic and Paralympic swimming featured a design in which the water was thought to mask the swimmer’s face too much and so there was a redesign (pictured above). By the time the design went out on circulating coins, the swimmer’s face was clearer. There is no information about how many were struck with the initial design, according to the Royal Mint. But last year one of the rare coins sold for £820. 
Overall, the London 2012 50p collection from The Royal Mint, which featured 29 designs, was so popular that more than 70 per cent are estimated to have been collected from circulation. As they are now very hard to find, it's worth hanging on to any that you spot. At the moment, they're not particularly valuable, selling for around £2-£3 on eBay, but in the future could be worth much more. Undated 20p There are thought to be a few undated 20 pence pieces in circulation, thanks to a 2008 error in the minting process. The coin without a date can be swapped for at least £100 at The Royal Mint's office in London - or possibly sold for more on eBay. 2002 Commonwealth Games £2 coin There are 485,5000 of the rarest £2 in circulation. If you find one of the coins in your pocket shrapnel, it can be sold on eBay for around £25. Or keep hold of it in the hope that it could be become worth much more. The rarest £1 coin The rarest £1 coin is the 2011 Edinburgh design, with a mintage of 935,000. The coin will typically sell for up to £5 on eBay, or keep it somewehere safe, as the value is likely to increase with time. Related articles
